scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded by acknowledging the difficulty and suggesting to prioritize tasks and see if additional resources are needed. As the team begins to break down the tasks, [Monica] seems hesitant and [Bob] looks frustrated. You advised the team to stay focused on what they can control, and suggested taking a short break before tackling the tasks one step at a time. The team considered escalating the issue to management for more support. However, [Monica] and [Bob] still seem uneasy.
scenes.description: [Monica] bites her lip and says: 'Even if we get more support, we still have to deal with the unrealistic expectations.' [Bob] adds: 'Yeah, and it's not like management will actually help us out. We're on our own here.'

options.text: I understand the frustration. Let's focus on what we can control right now and keep pushing forward.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the team's feelings while encouraging them to focus on what they can control, showing good interpersonal balance and social skills.

options.text: I hear you. Maybe we need to have a candid conversation with management about the unrealistic expectations.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the concerns and proposed a practical solution, showing good emotional perception and communication skills.

options.text: I get it. If anyone has a better idea, now's the time to speak up. Otherwise, we stick to the plan.
options.analysis: You invited alternative suggestions, showing good communication skills, but emotional perception and interpersonal balance could be improved.
